meeting_annotations.speaker: Amanda Stockton
meeting_annotations.transcript: using it to search for similar molecules in uh extraterrestrial environments. Um, another large part of my group is looking at what is the um spatial distribution of um bio signatures in recently resurfaced areas where um bio load is low and there's not much input from um anthropogenic or macrofauna um contamination such as uh the um volcanoes in Iceland. So uh I feel like Chris and I probably have some things to talk about there. Um, but we're also interested in those uh spatial distributions and um heterogeneity in uh sampling in order to help inform how to best sample such that you are accurately measuring what you're attempting to measure whenever you cross gradients uh in volcanic regimes, hydrothermal regimes, um recently we've started working more in hypersaline regimes as well.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great. Is it worth me going through our brief, well not so brief, but uh description of so we are extremes of habitability. This list is is actually quite specific and I'm probably we're going to want to go beyond it, but how do organisms survive in extreme environments such as in concentrated brines and how do brines function as refugia during times of environmental crisis. Are there environmental or chemical constraints on on the environments most likely.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: This is weirdly worded. Are there are there environmental and chemical constraints on the environment that most likely are able to support the initiation or proliferation of life. What types of conditions should we seek out in our search.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: For example for example the Kepler discovered small planet population appears to include a large number of erotic cores of broadly Neptune like planets under what conditions would such cores become habitable planets. Um that's very specific. We don't necessarily have to dwell on that for too long.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: One one idea that I had for catalyzing the discussion and Tori please um weigh in on this is what exactly we mean by extreme. What what is the definition of extreme and over what range of conditions physical, chemical, biological and otherwise competitive strategies and so forth. Um what what is extreme to life. Um and how might these play out in different systems. So there's the example of brines, salinity but there are obviously many other parameters to play with. Does that seem like a place to start?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Tori Hoehler
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yep, I think that's a great place to start.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Marlow
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I I you know, often we think about extremophiles and then the pushback is that it's extreme to us and not extreme to them, which I think is fair. So to me sometimes the the definition is more about the like rate of change of an environment and if you're really challenging something to respond to drastic changes in energy or environmental stress at a rate that's incommensurate with evolutionary change then that becomes pretty pretty extreme.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Aaron Engelhart
meeting_annotations.transcript: One of the points Lynn Rothschild always makes in her talks about extremophiles is that you and I are technically extremophiles because we're living in the presence of such a high concentration of oxygen and I think she kind of says it to be provocative but there's some truth to that I feel like too.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Solange Duhamel
meeting_annotations.transcript: For me it also comes to the the diversity of microorganisms because basically when you are in an environment that is very really extreme you you have a decrease in in diversity. And so uh I I suppose this is a good um a good proxy to to to define what a extreme environment would be for life. Because only specific really specialized organisms are able to to survive and thrive in those environments.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: We have an addition, Rachel. Hi.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rachel Parker
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, sorry, interloper here. Uh I'm I'm uh from the that from Cfar, the Canadian Institute for Advanced Research. Um and just an interloper. Um I run our Cfar Azrieli Global Scholars program. So thanks for letting me sit in.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well we were so we were just talking about what what is extreme, what does that mean.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Amanda Stockton
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, I have a question that comes from the fact that um I haven't taken biology since my freshman year of college. Um, do we have any known communities of or not a community, but um, known environments where a single microorganism alone.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Amanda Stockton
meeting_annotations.transcript: Survives on its own or are we usually talking about communities because I should know the answer to this but I'm always looking at communities in my extreme environments.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: They're rare. There's a good example from the deep sub surface um some at least one South African gold mine bore hole was found to be inhabited by a mono phyletic community of this.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, although other bore holes in the same couple are more complex environment very diverse life and that's certainly not a a dominant feature of the concept surface.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Amanda Stockton
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, so if that is the lone one is is it because our techniques may have missed a community or is it like really well nailed down that that is the single um organism populating that line.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh that that was one bore hole. Um one site within that mine. The others are more diverse. So certainly not the whole mine but at that time point at that moment in time.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Amanda Stockton
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, I guess my my question is like.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Amanda Stockton
meeting_annotations.transcript: What is the certainty that it was just one or um I know with our micro bioanalytical uh techniques we keep um finding out that where we thought there was relative simplicity in a community it turns out to be more and more complex as we learn more about how to actually analyze these environments.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: The original detection was a clone library which is by no means an exhaustive uh search for microbial diversity but I believe it's been confirmed with or it's been um further treated with some shotgun metagenomics which is getting a little bit more detailed in the detection structure.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um I also did kind of an interesting survey um at NASA Goddard who's of agnostic bio signature thing trying to look uh for and this was actually with a Cfar program with 40 uh fellows um trying to look uh for places of no life detection.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: So where can you get to extreme environments where you actually don't get anything and it turns out that that's a really interesting uh way to search because you're essentially, you know, people like to report results and so you're looking for like the things that didn't work in people's data and so.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: For people working on the edge it's like, well we, you know, six out of 15 of these amplified and we got measurable this and that out of this and we're like, yes, but what about those nine? Tell us about those. So there's a lot of like awkward emails where it's like, we see you had some samples that didn't work. Elaborate.
